CHAPTER 721
Junkyards
 
721.01    Nuisance conditions.
721.02    Fencing requirements.
721.03    Evidence.
721.99    Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      State licensing and required fencing - see Ohio R.C. 4737.05 et seq.
      Junk vehicles - see TRAF.
303.09,
303.10
 
 
   721.01  NUISANCE CONDITIONS.
   The establishment, operation or maintenance of a place by any person, firm
or corporation for the purpose of carrying on or engaging in the operation of a
junkyard or other place for the collection or storage of rags or motor vehicles
not bearing a current license plate, scrap iron, rubber, paper, or any
combination thereof within the Village and not fenced as herein required is
hereby declared to be a junkyard nuisance and an impairment to the health,
safety and welfare of the citizens and inhabitants of the Village.
(Ord. 70-7. Passed 6-16-70.)
 
   721.02 FENCING REQUIREMENTS.
   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the establishment, operation
or maintenance of a place described in Section
721.01 hereof, or suffer the same to exist on property in whole or part owned
by him with the present right of occupancy, unless there is erected and
maintained completely around the same a nontransparent metal fence at least
eight feet high and beginning at the surface of the ground and so constructed
to prevent the deposit within, through or under such fence, of any garbage or
household refuse at any place from the surface of the ground to the top
thereof, and completely encircling such place or places, including a similarly
nontransparent and restricting gate or gates, which shall remain closed and
locked at all times when an owner or employee of such establishment shall not
be in attendance. Such fence and gates shall be neatly kept plumb and even,
without holes or rust, and free of all advertising save only the name of the
business operated within.
(Ord. 70-7. Passed 6-16-70.)
 
   721.03 EVIDENCE.
   A showing that garbage or household refuse is present within such enclosure
after September 1, 1970 shall be prima facie evidence that the enclosure
described herein is not constructed and/or maintained in accordance with this
chapter.
(Ord. 70-7. Passed 6-16-70.)
 
   721.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day on which a violation continues shall be deemed a separate
offense.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 731
Mechanical Amusement Devices
 
731.01    Definitions.
731.02    License required.
731.03    Issuance of license.
731.04    Inspection.
731.05    Restriction on hours.
731.06    General provisions.
731.07    Gambling prohibited.
731.08    Revocation of license; appeal.
731.99    Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Disturbing the peace - see GEN. OFF.
509.03
      Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
      Slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
      Tampering with coin machine - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
 
 
   731.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Game room, card room or amusement arcade" means a place of business
within a building or any part of a building having more than two mechanical or
electrically operated amusement devices or one or more card or domino tables
which are used for the purpose of public entertainment through the operation,
use or play, of any table game or device commonly known as electronic or
pinball games, or any pool or billiard tables, which are operated by placing
therein any coin, plate, disc, plug, key or token of value or by the payment of
a fee.
   (b)    "Mechanical or electronically operated amusement device" means any
coin operated machine, device or instrument, which upon the insertion of a
coin, token, slug or payment of a fee, operates or may be operated for use as a
game, contest of skill, or amusement, of any description and which in no way
intends to encourage gambling.
   (c)    "Card or domino table" means any piece of furniture, surface or
counter upon which a game of cards or domino are played.
   (d)    "Owner" means any person having possession of any mechanical or
electrical amusement device or any card or domino table or any person operating
an amusement arcade, game room or card room.
 
   731.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)    No person being the owner of a game room, card room or amusement
arcade shall display for public patronage or keep for operation by the public,
any mechanical or electrical amusement device, card or domino table without
first obtaining a license issued by the Mayor or his authorized agent in
accordance with this chapter.
 
   (b)    Each owner of a business with two or less mechanical or electrical
amusement devices shall pay an annual license fee of twenty-five dollars
($25.00) for each mechanical or electrical amusement device located in such
business.
   (c)    Each owner of a game room, card room, or amusement arcade shall pay
the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year for an annual license for the game
room, card room or amusement arcade. In addition, such owner shall also pay the
annual license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each electrical or
mechanical amusement device or card or domino table located in the game room,
card room or amusement arcade.
   (d)    The licenses required herein shall not be transferable to any other
person.
   (e)    No license shall be issued until an application is submitted to the
Mayor or his agent, which application shall, among other things state:
      (1)    The name, address, phone number, age and date of birth of the
applicant.
      (2)    The location, address, where the mechanical or electrical
amusement devices, card or domino tables are to be displayed or operated and
the business conducted therein.
      (3)    A description of the machine or machines to be covered by the
license, their serial numbers and the name of the manufacturer.
      (4)    The name of the owner or owners of the building wherein the
devices and/or tables are to be displayed or operated.
      (5)    The name of the owner or owners of the business conducted therein.
      (6)    The name and address of the owner of the machines and/or tables,
if the person is different than the applicant.
      (7)    Whether or not the applicant or the owner of the business has been
convicted of a gambling offense or for the conviction of a drug offense in the
last ten years prior to the date of application.
 
   731.03 ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   (a)    If the applicant for the license has filed the proper application and
has paid the proper fee as specified in Section
731.02 hereof, and the Mayor or his agent is satisfied that all information
requested is properly given, then a license shall be issued.
   (b)    The game room, card room or amusement arcade license shall be
displayed in a prominent place in the business establishment. It shall be the
duty of the owner to display such license during the period covered by the
license.
   (c)    For the purpose of this chapter, all licenses shall terminate on
December 31 of each calendar year and there shall be no prorating of fees. If
any licensed machine, device or table is replaced or substituted during the
registration period, a new application for such machine, device, or table must
be submitted with a five dollar ($5.00) fee. The Mayor or his agent shall then
issue a new license for such machine, device or table for the balance of the
registration period.
 
   731.04 INSPECTION.
   The owner of every game room, card room or amusement arcade shall at all
times, permit access to the Mayor or any law enforcement officer, for the
purpose of periodical inspection of the establishment, the mechanical or
electrical amusement devices or the card and domino tables.
 
   731.05  RESTRICTION ON HOURS.
   The owner shall prominently display in his place of business the curfew laws
of the Village. It shall be the duty of the owner to ascertain if his patrons
are violating such curfew laws, and if so, to eject them from the
establishment.
 
   731.06 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (a)    No owner shall permit the consumption of intoxicants or alcoholic
beverages by any person on said premises unless the owner holds a proper permit
from the Ohio State Liquor Control Board.
   (b)    All game rooms, card rooms or amusement arcades shall, during hours
of operation provide adult management. Adult means such person is eighteen
years of age or older.
   (c)    The owner of any game room, card room or amusement arcade shall
provide the necessary security personnel to police the interior and exterior
portion of the game room, card room, or amusement arcade.
   (d)    It shall be the obligation of the owner to maintain peace and quiet
in and about the game room, card room or amusement arcade. Failure to do so
shall constitute a nuisance and may be grounds for revocation of licenses.
   (e)    Owners of a business with two or less mechanical or electrical
amusement devices shall be subject to all provisions of this chapter except the
fee required for a game room or amusement arcade license.
 
   731.07  GAMBLING PROHIBITED.
   (a)    The owner of any game room, card room or amusement arcade shall
prominently display a sign indicating that gambling is prohibited. It shall
further be indicated on the sign that it shall be considered to be a gambling
offense if a player agrees to pay for the game of another upon the loss of a
game.
   (b)    No electronic or mechanical device shall be permitted that has as its
object the skill of winning at the playing of cards, dice, craps or roulette.
   (c)    No checks, tokens, chips or money of any kind shall exchange hands on
the outcome of a game except the check or checks issued by the owner and
collection from the players being limited to not more than one twenty-five cent
($. 25) check for each player engaged in such a game. The owner shall be held
strictly accountable for violation of this rule.
   (d)    The check must bear the business name and address. Checks will be
good for "in trade only" at business location printed on check. Such checks may
not be exchanged for cash.
 
   731.08 REVOCATION OF LICENSE; APPEAL.
   The Chief of Police may suspend or revoke any license issued pursuant to
this chapter for the direct or indirect violation of any of the provisions
hereof. ln the event that the Chief of Police suspends or revokes any license,
the owner may within ten days appeal such suspension or revocation to the
Mayor. If the Mayor upholds the suspension or revocation; the owner may appeal
to Council within ten days from the Mayor's decision. The decision of the
Council shall be final.
 
   731.99 PENALTY.
   In addition to the revocation provisions in Section
731.08 hereof, whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty
of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 741
Peddlers and Solicitors
 
741.01    Registration; fee.
741.02    Registration, transfer and use.
741.03    Definitions.
741.04    Exceptions.

741.06    Appeals.

741.08    Harassing or annoying prospective customers; trespass.
741.09    Peddling prohibited where signs posted.
741.10    Calling attention to sales by calling out, blowing horns, etc.
741.11    Carrying or exhibiting registration.
741.12    Revocation of registration.
741.13    Posting bills.
741.99    Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
      Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.21 et seq.
      Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
      Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
      Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
 541.05
 
 
   741.01 REGISTRATION; FEE.
   No person shall engage in the business of peddler, solicitor, canvasser or
itinerant merchant, as defined in Section
741.03 or solicit sales of, sell, offer for sale, barter, or exchange goods,
wares or personal services without paying the required fee and registering.
(Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.02  REGISTRATION, TRANSFER AND USE.
   (a)    Any peddler, solicitor, canvasser or itinerant merchant may engage in
their business after reporting to the Chief of Police, registering and paying a
fee of five dollars ($5.00). The period of time for which the registration
shall be valid shall be recorded by the Chief of Police but in no case shall
the registration period last more than one year. All fees shall be paid in
advance. Upon payment of the fee, the applicant shall be furnished with a copy
of this chapter and a receipt of their registration.
   (b)    No registration receipt shall be in any manner assignable or
transferable. No registration receipt shall authorize any person other than the
one named in such receipt to do business, nor shall a registrant conduct any
other business than is named therein be transacted.
(Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following words or phrases shall have
the following meanings:
   (a)    "Itinerant merchant or vendor" means a person with a fixed place of
business in the Village, but who on no more than three days in one calendar
year offers goods or services for sale at places other than his fixed place of
business.
   (b)   "Peddler" means any person with no fixed place of business in the
Village who carries wares or goods with him which he is prepared to sell at the
time he solicits business, and who deals primarily with consumers. The word
"peddler" includes the words "hawker" and "huckster".
   (c)    "Solicitor or canvasser" means a person with no fixed place of
business in the Village dealing primarily with consumers, who takes orders for
goods for future delivery or for personal services to be furnished in the
future, whether by telephone, or by house-to-house or business-to-business
canvassing.
      (Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.04 EXCEPTIONS.
   The requirements of a fee and registering as provided herein shall not apply
to:
   (a)    A duly authorized solicitor soliciting the sale of goods or wares for
or on behalf of any recognized educational, civic, religious or charitable
organization.
   (b)    Agents or salesmen of wholesale houses or firms selling or offering
to sell their wares or merchandise by sample to merchants in the Village, nor
to farmers selling or offering for sale the products of their own farms.
      (Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.05  REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    Applications for registration for peddlers, solicitors and itinerant
merchants, as defined in this chapter, must be filed with the Chief of Police
on a form to be furnished by the Chief of Police. The forms shall contain the
following information:
      (1)    Name of applicant;
      (2)    Home address;
      (3)    Name and address of the person by whom employed;
      (4)    Length of service with such employer;
      (5)    All places of residence and all employment during the preceding
year;
      (6)    The nature and character of the goods to be sold or service to be
furnished by the applicant; and
      (7)    Period of time for which registration is valid.
   (b)    If the Chief of Police determines after an investigation that the
applicant is of good moral character and proposes to engage in a lawful
commercial or professional enterprise, such registration shall be made.
(Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.06  APPEALS.
   Any applicant who has paid their fee and registered in accordance with this
chapter and whom the Chief of Police has, after investigation, denied a
registration shall be entitled to appeal to Council.
(Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.07  LIMITATIONS.
   (a)    No activity permitted under the authority of this chapter shall
commence prior to 9:00 a.m., nor continue after 5:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time
or prior to 9:00 a.m. nor continue after 9:00 p.m. Eastern Daylight Savings
Time, except for the occasional special event(s) sponsored by Village merchants
as noted by the Chief of Police on the registration form.
   (b)    No peddler, canvasser, solicitor or itinerant merchant shall operate
in the War Memorial Park without permission of the Park Board. No peddler,
canvasser, solicitor or itinerant merchant shall operate at the Village Pool or
in any building owned by the Village with the exception of the Village
Auditorium governed by the rules that the Chief of Police from time to time may
impose for its use.
(Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.08 HARASSING OR ANNOYING PROSPECTIVE CUSTOMERS; TRESPASS.
   No peddler, canvasser, solicitor, or itinerant merchant shall vex, annoy or
harass any person by importuning such person to purchase or look at his goods
or wares; nor shall any peddler, canvasser, solicitor or itinerant merchant
enter any private house of residence without being invited to come in.
(Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.09 PEDDLING PROHIBITED WHERE SIGNS POSTED.
   No peddler, canvasser, solicitor or itinerant merchant shall knock at the
door of or ring the bell of any private home, apartment or apartment building
in the Village where there is displayed at the entrance a notice reading "No
Solicitors, Peddlers or Canvassers Allowed", or which otherwise clearly
purports to prohibit person from doing so, unless such person is or has been
invited upon such premises by the owner, lessee or occupant thereof.
(Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.10  CALLING ATTENTION TO SALES BY CALLING OUT, BLOWING HORNS, ETC.
   No peddler, canvasser, solicitor or itinerant merchant in going along the
streets, alleys or other public places of the Village shall call out, cry or by
the use of any sound producing or sound amplification device, make any loud or
objectionable noise, or blow any horn to call attention to the sale of any
goods, wares, merchandise or any articles or things whatsoever.
(Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.11 CARRYING OR EXHIBITING REGISTRATION.
   The receipt of registration issued by the Chief of Police shall be carried
by any peddler, solicitor, canvasser, or itinerant merchant when operating away
from his fixed place of business and shall be exhibited to any person solicited
or any police officer on request.
(Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.12 REVOCATION OF REGISTRATION.
   (a)    Registration issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the
Chief of Police after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes:
      (1)    Fraud, misrepresentation or any false statement contained in the
application for a registration.
      (2)    Fraud, misrepresentation of any false statement made to the Police
Department in furnishing the information required by this chapter.
      (3)    Any violation of this chapter.
      (4)    Conviction of the registrant of any felony or crime involving
moral turpitude.
      (5)    Conducting the soliciting or peddling in an unlawful manner, or in
such a manner as to constitute a breach of peace or to be a menace to the
health, safety or general welfare of the public.
   (b)    Notice of the hearing for revocation of a registration shall be given
by the Chief of Police in writing stating the grounds of the complaint and the
time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to
the registrant at the address given on the application for the registration, at
least five days prior to the date set for the hearing.
   (c)    Any person aggrieved by the decision of the Chief of Police shall
have the right to appeal to Council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with
the Fiscal Officer a written statement of the grounds for the appeal within
fourteen days after notice of the decision by the Chief of Police has been
given. Council shall set the time and place for hearing such appeal, and notice
of such time and place shall be given by the Fiscal Officer in the manner
herein provided for notice of hearing of revocation by the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
   741.13  POSTING BILLS.
   (a)    No person shall post, by attaching in any manner, any bill,
advertisement, notice or poster of any kind whatsoever, excluding Municipal,
State and Federal Notices, on any tree, fence, telegraph, telephone or electric
power pole, building or other property situated upon any of the streets, alleys
or public grounds of the Village.
   (b)    Whoever violates this section is guilty of posting bills, a minor
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 88-26. Passed 9-20-88.)
 
   741.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and, in addition, his registration may be revoked. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues.
(Ord. 83-14. Passed 10-18-83.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 751
Alarm Systems
 
751.01   Definitions.
751.02   Alarm permits.
751.03   Alarm fees.
751.04   Automatic dialing devices.
751.05   Equipment maintenance and inspection of alarm systems.
751.06   Suspension, revocation and appeals procedure for permits.
751.07   Liability of Village.
751.08   Exemptions.
751.99   Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
False alarms - see GEN. OFF.
 509.07
 
 
   751.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, certain terms and words are defined as
follows:
   (a)   “Alarm permit” means a permit issued by the Chief of Police to any
owner or other person in control of a building or buildings, property or part
thereof, to install and maintain an alarm system.
   (b)   “Alarm system” means any assembly of equipment and devices which
signals so as to be seen or heard outside the protected building or space, the
presence of fire, smoke, robbery, burglary, vandalism or unauthorized
intrusion.
   (c)   “Interconnected alarm system” means an alarm system which directly or
indirectly, automatically or manually uses a communication conveyance to
transmit an alarm or message upon activation of the alarm system, and that such
transmission is eventually delivered to the Village police.
   (d)   “Local alarm system” means an alarm system that when activated only
sounds a horn, bell, buzzer, or other type of audible or visible alarm that is
designed to be audible or visible beyond the premises being served, but which
does not result in the transmission of a signal to any other location.
   (e)   “Alarm permit holder” means a person, organization or company who has
a permit issued to him by the Chief of Police.
   (f)   “Appropriate Chief” means the Ada Chief of Police or his designee.
   (g)   “Automatic dialing service” means a device which is interconnected to
a telephone line and is programmed to select a predetermined telephone number
and transmit by voice, message or code signal an emergency message indicating
the need for emergency response.
   (h)   "False alarm" means an alarm signal or message initiated and
transmitted either automatically or manually through an alarm system, to the
Village eliciting response by police or fire personnel when fire, smoke,
robbery, burglary, vandalism or unauthorized intrusion does not, in fact,
exist, but does not include an alarm signal caused by acts of God not
reasonably subject to control by the alarm manufacturer, installer or alarm
permit holder.
      (Ord. 86-3. Passed 3-18-86.)
 
   751.02 ALARM PERMITS.
   (a)   Any residence or building or part thereof may be equipped with an
alarm system for the purpose of detecting and signaling the presence of a fire
or unauthorized intrusion.
   (b)   Before an interconnected alarm system is installed in a residence or
building, the owner must apply for a permit from the Chief of Police. The Chief
shall prescribe the form of the application and request such information as is
necessary to evaluate and act upon permit application. The information
contained in an alarm permit application shall be securely maintained and
restricted to inspection only by the Chief of Police or his designee.
   (c)   An alarm installation permit fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be
charged for a permit issued under the provisions of this chapter. The initial
fee shall be waived for permit holders sixty-five years or older for alarm
systems on their residences only.
   (d)   Any person, organization or business which currently has an
interconnected alarm system installed in their residence or place of business
shall apply for an alarm permit within thirty days of the effective date of
this chapter, and shall not be billed the ten dollars ($10.00) for the permit.
After thirty days, a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fee will be applied.
   (e)   When there has occurred any material change in the information
previously submitted with respect to such alarm system, it shall be the duty of
the occupant of a building served by an alarm system within ten days after the
change in information previously submitted to the Village to file an
application supplement containing accurate current information with respect to
the data required by the Chief.
(Ord. 86-3. Passed 3-18-86.)
 
   751.03 ALARM FEES.
   Any activation of the alarm system including false alarms shall result in a
charge of zero dollars ($0.00) per activation to be billed semi-annually to the
permit holder. Any activation of an alarm system constituting a false alarm
shall be recorded to the location as a false alarm for the purpose of Section
751.99(b).
(Ord. 95-27. Passed 11-7-95.)
 
   751.04 AUTOMATIC DIALING DEVICES.
   No person shall use or cause to be used, any telephone device or telephone
attachment that automatically selects any telephone line allocated by the
telephone company to the Village or any of its departments or divisions.
(Ord. 86-3. Passed 3-18-86.)
 
   751.05 EQUIPMENT MAINTENANCE AND INSPECTION OF ALARM SYSTEMS.
   (a)    All equipment used in installations for which a permit is required
shall meet the applicable standards of the Underwriters Laboratories of the
United States and of Canada, Factory Mutual, or the National Fire Protection
Association, or other recognized industry standard. The installer may be
required to submit evidence of the reliability and suitability of the equipment
to be installed.
   (b)    The Chief of Police may require that repairs or adjustments be made
whenever he has determined that such are necessary to assure proper operation.
Failure to make such repairs or adjustments may be grounds for revocation of
the alarm permit, requiring a reapplication for a new permit which must be
accompanied by evidence of repairs or adjustments.
(Ord. 86-3. Passed 3-18-86.)
 
   751.06 SUSPENSION, REVOCATION AND APPEALS PROCEDURE FOR PERMITS.
   (a)    Before a permit issued pursuant to this chapter may be suspended, or
revoked for any reason except as prescribed in Section
751.99, a hearing must be held before the Chief. A notice setting forth the
time, place and nature of the hearing shall be sent to the alarm permit holder
no less than seven days prior to such hearing.
   (b)    After the hearing, the Chief shall either dismiss the case or shall
forward a recommendation of revocation to the Mayor. Within ten days after
receiving the recommendation, the Mayor shall approve or disapprove the
recommendation and notify the permit holder accordingly.
(Ord. 86-3. Passed 3-18-86.)
 
   751.07  LIABILITY OF VILLAGE.
   The issuance of any permits in conjunction with this chapter shall not
constitute acceptance by the Village or any liability to maintain any
equipment, to answer alarms or for anything in connection therewith.
(Ord. 86-3. Passed 3-18-86.)
 
   751.08  EXEMPTIONS.
   (a)    The provisions of this chapter are not applicable to home smoke
detectors not intended to be heard outside the dwelling unit, nor to local
alarm systems or audible alarm affixed to automobiles, boats, boat trailers,
house trailers and recreation vehicles or other motor vehicles.
   (b)   A financial institution required by State or Federal law or
regulations to maintain an alarm system shall be exempt from the revocation
sections of this chapter but shall be subject to penalties for violation of
this chapter.
(Ord. 86-3. Passed 3-18-86.)
 
   751.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   No person shall operate an alarm system without first obtaining a
permit as required by this chapter, or after having a permit revoked, fail to
disconnect the alarm system. Violation of this section shall be a minor
misdemeanor. Each day of such unpermitted use shall constitute a separate
violation. (Ord. 86-3. Passed 3-18-86.)
   (b)   After six officially chargeable false alarms in any six month period,
the Chief of Police will review the alarm holder’s permit and recommend to the
Mayor continuance of the permit or revoking of the permit. The Chief of Police
may order the disconnection of any alarm system upon forwarding a
recommendation of revocation of an alarm permit to the Mayor pending his
review.
   No permit holder shall fail to disconnect his alarm system upon order of the
Chief of Police as set forth herein. Violation of this section shall be a minor
misdemeanor.
(Ord. 95-27. Passed 11-7-95.)
   (c)   No alarm permit holder shall knowingly allow his alarm system to be
used by any person to create a false alarm as defined in the Ohio Revised Code.
Violation of this section shall be a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(Ord. 86-3. Passed 3-18-86.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 761
Video Service Providers
761.01   Fee.
   761.01 FEE.   
   (a)   Council hereby establishes a VSP Fee that is calculated by applying a
VSP Fee Percentage of five percent (5%) to the video service provider’s gross
revenues as defined in Section 1332.32(B) of the Video Law. All video service
providers and cable television operators providing video service in the Village
shall apply the VSP Fee Percentage against gross revenues as defined in the
Video Law.
   (b)   The VSP Fee shall be paid by each video service provider providing
service in the Village on a quarterly basis but not sooner that forty-five days
nor later than sixty days after the end of each calendar quarter.
   (c)   The Mayor is authorized and directed to provided any video service
provider with notice of the VSP Fee Percentage as determined by this Council
above, which notice shall be given by certified mail, upon receipt of notice
from such video service provider that it will begin providing video service in
the Village pursuant to a state-issued video service authorization.
(Res. 2009-02. Passed 3-17-09.)

CHAPTER 905
Sidewalks
905.01    Sidewalk specifications.
905.02    Sidewalk Cost Sharing Program (50%/50%).
905.03    Inspections.
905.04    Notice to repair.
905.05    Work done by Village; assessment against property.
905.06    Emergencies.
905.07    Authority of Administrator to modify regulations.
905.08    Nuisance conditions prohibited.
905.99    Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Construction or repair at owner's expense - see Ohio R.C.729.01 et seq.
      Notice to construct or repair sidewalks - see Ohio R.C. 729.03 et seq.
      Duty to keep sidewalks clean and in repair - see GEN. OFF.
521.06
 
 
   905.01 SIDEWALK SPECIFICATIONS.
   All sidewalks shall be constructed, reconstructed, or repaired under the
supervision of the Village. The work shall be constructed in accordance with
the Design Standards and Specifications of the Village.
   (a)   Material: All sidewalks are to be concrete or brick pavers. Asphalt is
permitted through parking lot areas or under special conditions approved by the
Village prior to construction. Sidewalk width shall be a minimum of 48 inches
or shall match the abutting walk, whichever is larger.
   (b)   All sidewalk repairs shall consist of a minimum of one complete
section using existing patterns and layouts in the repaired walk. An asphalt
overlay of brick or concrete walks is not permitted under any circumstance.
   (c)   Normal sidewalk construction is for walks to be placed upon both sides
of the right-of-way. Council and/or Ada Planning Commission may waive this
requirement.
   (d)   Council may require sidewalks to be constructed at the property
owner’s expense, due to increased foot traffic, safety issues and/or continuity
of foot traffic and sidewalks. (Ord. 2006-12. Passed 11-7-06.)
 
   905.02 SIDEWALK COST SHARING PROGRAM (50%/50%).
   The Village has established a sidewalk program to allow for cost sharing for
construction and/or reconstruction of sidewalks. The cost sharing components of
the sidewalk program are as follows:
   (a)   Property owners requesting program participation shall sign up within
the year prior to the work being completed.
   (b)   At the first of each year, the Village shall request bids for work
requested. If funds are not adequate to cover requests, the Village shall
prioritize work based upon location and foot traffic.
   (c)   Once bids are received, the property owner will be required to pay
their share before the work is started. If payment is not received by the
designated date, their request will be removed from that year’s work schedule.
This is a 50% sidewalk cost sharing program with the Village’s share of the
cost being the cost of concrete and labor to meet the Village’s basic sidewalk
standards.
   (d)   All work must comply with the Village’s current design standards and
specifications. The Village has full authority to accept and/or reject any work
requested by a property owner.
   (e)   Only sidewalks on public right of way are eligible. The Village shall
be responsible for corners and alleys. Driveway approaches are not eligible for
the sidewalk cost sharing program.
   (f)   Work that shall be performed by the Village’s contractor includes
removal and replacement of sidewalk, placement of fill dirt and rough grading
around the new work. The property owner shall be responsible for finishing the
construction area, including fine grading, seeding and watering. All adjoining
walks shall be brought to grade to eliminate any possible safety hazard, even
if the section is not eligible for the sidewalk cost sharing program. In the
event the section is not eligible, the property owner shall bear full financial
responsibility for that work. When possible, this determination shall be set
forth prior to commencement of any work. The Village has full authority to
accept or reject all work performed by the contractor.
   (g)   The Village shall work with the property owner so it is very clear
what work is to be done, including square footage, approximate elevation
change, tapered sections, and tree root damage and/or tree removal. A work
agreement between the Village and the property owner may be required to address
access issues and any special problems related to each property.
   (h)   The Village shall not permit cost sharing for new homes, areas which
currently do not have sidewalks, brick pavers, colored or stamped concrete, any
construction beyond the Village’s basic sidewalk standards, or to any property
that has been issued a Notice to Repair for nuisance issues, except with the
approval of Council.
   (i)   The sidewalk cost sharing program will only be available to property
owners when Village funds have been budgeted for such purposes. Funds shall be
available on a first come, first serve basis. Preference will be given to the
Safe Routes to School travel plan, if applicable. The property owner must sign
a cost sharing agreement before being accepted into the program, and payment
must be received prior to any work being performed.
   (j)   Request for participation in the sidewalk cost sharing program does
not relieve any property owner of liability due to owner’s failure to maintain
or repair the sidewalk or keep the sidewalk free from hazards.
      (Ord. 2014-14. Passed 12-2-14.)
 
   905.03 INSPECTIONS.
   All sidewalk installations must have two inspections by the Village. First
inspection is to be conducted after the forms are set, but before the concrete
is in place. Second inspection is to be conducted after the concrete is placed
and the forms are removed. A 24-hour notice to the Village is required for all
inspections.
(Ord. 2006-12. Passed 11-7-06.)
 
   905.04  NOTICE TO REPAIR.
   (a)   The Village shall inspect sidewalks to determine whether they create a
hazard. The Village shall investigate all complaints filed by any citizen
alleging that a sidewalk creates a hazard.
   (b)   A property owner (or owner of the lot abutting such sidewalk) will be
notified to repair a sidewalk if it is severely cracked, chipped or broken and/
or there is a grade variation of not less than 3/4 inch between sections.
   (c)   Whenever the Village Administrator finds that a sidewalk should be
constructed or that a paved sidewalk or sidewalk area, including driveways and
the grass strip, is not in good repair or is not free from nuisance, he shall
cause the owner of the property (or owners of the lot abutting such sidewalk)
to be notified in writing, to have the necessary construction, reconstruction
or repairs made. Such notice shall be served on the owner or his agent in the
manner provided by law for the service of summons in civil action. For the
purpose of such service, any person charged with the collection of rent or the
payment of taxes on the property, or having general control of it in any way,
shall be considered the agent of the owner. Construction or reconstruction
shall be completed within sixty days from the date of service of notice, unless
the time is extended by the Village Council.
   (d)   Where there is no resident owner in Hardin County, or no agent
available for service of notice or the place of residence of the owner cannot
be found, the notice shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general
circulation in the Village.
(Ord. 2006-12. Passed 11-7-06.)  
 
   905.05 WORK DONE BY VILLAGE; ASSESSMENT AGAINST PROPERTY.
   If sidewalks are not constructed, or if defective sidewalks are not
reconstructed, or repaired or freed from nuisance within the period of time
permitted by the notice to the owner of the abutting property, or extensions of
time granted as provided above, the Administrator shall prepare a list of such
sidewalks that have not been corrected and present the same to Council, which
shall proceed, as proved in Ohio Revised Code 729.01 through 729.11 to cause
the necessary construction to be made and to assess the entire cost against the
property owner (or owner of the lot abutting such sidewalk).
(Ord. 2006-12. Passed 11-7-06.)
 
   905.06  EMERGENCIES.
   In case of emergency such as destruction of or substantial damage to a
sidewalk from flood, explosion or other event, the Village Administrator shall
otherwise provide for the public safety. The cost of all such emergency repair
and protection shall be charged to the property owner. Permanent repairs shall
be made as provided by this chapter.
(Ord. 2006-12. Passed 11-7-06.)
 
   905.07 AUTHORITY OF ADMINISTRATOR TO MODIFY REGULATIONS.
   If at any time, it is found that the sidewalk and driveway provisions herein
provided for are impractical under certain circumstances, the Administrator is
authorized to use his discretion in modifying the strict application of same in
order to obtain what is reasonable and at the same time safe and convenient for
both the public and the owner. In cases where the owner is dissatisfied with
the modifications made by the Administrator, the property owner (or owner of
the lot abutting such sidewalk) may appeal to the Village Council, whose
decision shall be final.
(Ord. 2006-12. Passed 11-7-06.)
 
   905.08 NUISANCE CONDITIONS PROHIBITED.
   (a)   The owners and or occupants or any person having the care of any
building, lot or land in the Village shall keep the entire width of any
sidewalk from the curb or edge of street to the lot line in front of or
alongside of such property free from filth, mud, dirt, merchandise, rubbish or
any nuisance, impediment or obstruction which may damage property of another or
injure any person traveling along or upon such sidewalk.
   (b)   The owners and or occupants or any person having the care of any
building, lot or land in the Village shall not cause filth, mud, dirt, rubbish
or any nuisance including snow or ice which they have removed from such
sidewalk, driveway or parking lot to be thrown into any public highway, alley,
street, or public place or on to the private property of another.
   (c)   No owner and or occupant or any person having the care of any building
or lot in the Village shall refuse, fail or neglect to repair and keep free
from nuisance and obstruction, the sidewalk in front or alongside of such
property after due notice, ordering the repair of such sidewalk, the removal of
such obstruction or the abatement of such nuisance.
   (d)   If the owners and or occupants or any person having the care of any
building or lot in the Village fails to comply with such notice, Council shall
cause the sidewalk to be repaired. All expenses and labor costs incurred shall
when approved by Council be paid out of municipal funds. Council shall make a
written return to the County Auditor of its action with a statement of the
charges for its services, the amount paid for labor, the fees of the officers
serving such notices and a proper description of the premises. Such amounts,
when allowed shall be entered upon the tax duplicate of the property owners or
owners of the lot abutting such sidewalk and are a lien upon such lands from
and after the date of the entry and be collected as other taxes and returned to
the Municipality.
(Ord. 2006-12. Passed 11-7-06.)
 
   905.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation continues or occurs.
(Ord. 2006-12. Passed 11-7-06.)

909.01   Design Criteria adopted.

CROSS REFERENCES

   909.01 DESIGN CRITERIA ADOPTED.
   (a)   The Design Criteria and the Construction Standards and Drawings
attached to Ordinance 99-29 and marked “Exhibit A” and made a part hereof as if
expressly rewritten herein is hereby adopted by the Village.
   (b)   No person shall located, erect, construct, reconstruct, enlarge,
change, maintain or use any building, equipment, or land in violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter, or any amendment or supplement thereto adopted
by Council. Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of
this chapter or any amendment of supplement thereto, shall be deemed guilty of
a misdemeanor of the third degree. Each and every day during which such
violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. The Village has the
right to withhold or terminate water and/or wastewater service until all
provisions comply with this chapter.
(Ord. 99-29. Passed 10-19-99.)
 
   909.02 BOND; PERMITS FOR THE USE OR OCCUPANCY OF STREETS AND RIGHTS OF WAY
